lines.text: What do you think is the difference between bravery and stupidity?
Same thing. Just depends on the timing.
Six confirmed kills.
Really? Outstanding! NVA or VC?
Monkeys. They didn't say which side they were on.

Why are we here? Because, we don't mean squat. We are second rate citizens. What about all the other people whose kids don't have to fight the war? Let's face it boys, we're the hicks, the spics and the niggers. That's why we're here.

[during combat, to VC]
I'm the nightmare your mama told you about!
I think she's gonna have a baby. Anybody know what we oughta do?
No idea.
Well, my mother had a baby.
Well, I hope so, Baker!
I guess when I'm drunk I can make a little sense of it all. I just want to know what the hell happened to me.
You get boom-boom. That's what happend to you.
[After a series of explosions]

[drunk]
Auntie Em, I don't think we're in Kansas anymore!
You gotta do it, Marcus! You're gonna get court marshaled, man!
What're they gonna do?! Send me to Vietnam?! Nigga, I am in Vietnam!
You just can't go bursting into a major's office!
What's he going to do? Send me to Vietnam? Make me a grunt?
What's the matter? Ain't none of you niggers ever seen a spic before?
Not an ugly one like you!
[The platoon is under heavy fire]
I think we should attack.
I think we should wait it out, sir.
Are you sure?
Well, we could call Gen. Wesmoreland right now, and discuss it!
Father, I just want to know what we're all doing in this godforsaken excuse of a country!
What we're doing here? Son, I'm here to give you comfort and support, but I'm often as confused as you are.
Man, you're lying again.
Yeah, well, I also kill people. That don't make me a bad person.
The chaplain wasn't congratulating you for what you did on the field. He was congratulating you for coming back alive.
If you ask me, sir, that's a stupid way to do it.
The army ain't asking, soldier.
If you're a conscientious objector, why did you come here instead of prison?
Didn't want to be some lifer's old lady.
You could've gone to Canada.
Allergic to moose.
You didn't answer my question, soldier. Why did you come to Vietnam instead of prison or Canada?
Well, because prison or Canada wouldn't have been positive experiences.
Let me tell you something, out in the field, Charlie can be a very negative experience.

I don't know what you're going through. But, if you think you're the only one who's hurting, you're dead wrong. What we saw there today... made me sick. If you keep taking those pills, you're putting your buddies at risk, while they're covering it for you.

That's not it, Doc. You see, I've been here too long. A long time ago, I just stopped caring. I was doing my best to feel anything. But then, I just realized I don't want to feel a damn thing anymore.

[about a village that was massacred by another American platoon]
You guys just don't get it. We killed those people. Even if we weren't the ones who pulled the triggers, we did it! What if it was back home? What if those were your sisters, your brothers, your parents? When I think about it, I want to puke my guts out! But, I can't... I've been here too damn long.
[After hearing Susanna's (an officer from a rich family) story about how she joined the army]
So, what are you doing here?
The president sent me.
Yet another memorial service brought to you courtesy of communist containment.
This is a war. There's casualties. Once you get past that, you can concentrate on winning.
Winning? Where the hell have you been?
I'm not like you, sir. I never had that many friends and I was never good at making any.
Good at making friends? Lieutenant Goldman's my best friend and he hates me!
[The platoon is upset because of dangerous patrols ordered by Goldman]
So, what do you think?
About what?
I... I was just thinking about my father.
You're talking about the first General Goldman?
He was Colonel Goldman back then. He was one tough son of a bitch. It's just that no matter what he did, the men liked him.
Listen to me, it's real easy to get these guys to like you. They'll like you, up until the time the base is overrun. Then there's gonna be only one person to blame...
[pokes Goldman's shoulder]
Over here, you're either scared or crazy... Or dead.
Congratulations! You just discovered the way to deal with the army.
Which is?
Yell at 'em.
You got a big mouth, you know that?
I was born with it.
You could die with it.
This place sucks!
500,000 troops in country and I get stuck with F Troop.
[The area behind the platoon is swarming with V.C.]
We got to check our rear.
I'll go.
I can't do that to you, Ruiz.
Don't worry about it, sir. It's like a walk through Central Park... Only half as dangerous.
What's wrong, Taylor?
It's my leg, sarge.
Your leg? You're sitting in a hole! How the hell'd you get shot in the leg?
That's the thing, I've been sitting here too long. I got the worst charlie horse I ever had.
You know what, Taylor? Every time I think I heard it all, all I gotta do is talk to you and realize that I ain't heard a damn thing yet.
Yes, this village is going to be a hallmark of what Americans and Vietnamese can accomplish when they work together. It might ever rub out some of that cynicism of yours, Sergeant.
I'm not cynical, sir. I'm just responsible for a lot of men who depend on me being realistic.
You will give us the coordinates, or I'll arrange for you to have a talk with my south Vietnamese colleague, here.
My country important. My life not important. You can't win.
Listen to me, colonel. You have never defeated us in the battlefield. We have superior firepower. We can bomb you back to the stone age.
You can't win. Unless you want to stay here and eat rice for the next thousand years, you can't win.
We're gonna go down and secure the village.
Seems like a wussy mission for special forces.
VC have been coming down there, collecting taxes from the locals. They haven't been paying so they started terrorizing them. Like it or not, it's our job.
You want to talk terrorist tactics? Take a look at what Uncle Sam did to your paycheck.
You can't win this war by killing every man, woman and child.
There's no other way.
Well, well, well. Purcell, you look as clean as a Mississippi sheriff on election day.
Where are you from, Lieutenant?
New York, sir. Queens.
You don't sound like it.
Thank you, sir.
Don't mention it.
[Sgt. Block kidnapped Purcell]
You in my jungle now, boy.
